questions.question: What is the role of temperature in the synthesis of copper(I) mixed ethynediide/isopropylethynide nanoclusters?
questions.answer: Temperature leverages the release of the active ethynediide dianion through concerted C@H/C@C single bond cleavage of iPr@C/C@H to initiate the formation of CuI mixed ethynediide/alkynide nanoclusters.

questions.question: How does the synthesis of nanoclusters 1–4 demonstrate the concept of a simple-input/complex-output model?
questions.answer: The synthesis involves a reciprocal cycle starting from the comproportionation reaction to generate CuI, which acts both as a catalyst for C2@ release and as a metal component for mixed-ligand cluster formation, leading to the consumption of CuI and driving the comproportionation reaction forward.

questions.question: What is the significance of the highest C2@ content in complex 4?
questions.answer: Complex 4, bearing the highest C2@ content, features an unprecedented nanoscale Cu2C2 kernel, demonstrating the emergence of template-dependent nanocluster growth and structural evolution.

questions.question: How does the co-existing anion (X@) influence the synthesis of nanoclusters 1–4?
questions.answer: The effect of the co-existing anion becomes amplified in the template-directed cluster formation reaction, giving rise to 1–4 as a systematic structural series of nanoclusters containing different C2@ contents.

questions.question: What role does the C2@ dianion play in the formation of copper(I) mixed ethynediide/alkynide nanoclusters?
questions.answer: The C2@ dianion acts as a structural template that diverts the CuI alkynide phase-formation pathway from polymers to discrete clusters, validating it as a structural template to dictate CuI alkynide cluster chemistry.

questions.question: What is the relationship between the C2@ content and the photophysical properties of nanoclusters 1–3?
questions.answer: The photophysical properties of 1–3, measured in the solid state, show that all emissions are phosphorescent in nature, with the lifetime decays all at a microsecond scale, indicating a relationship between the C2@ content and their structure-controlled photoluminescence.

questions.question: What is the effect of increasing the temperature to a solvothermal level of 120 88C during the synthesis process?
questions.answer: Elevating the temperature to a solvothermal level of 120 88C results in uncontrollable C@H/C@C single bond cleavage with overwhelming generation of the reactive C2@ species, leading to highly explosive [CuI/C/C]1 complexes.

questions.question: How does the structural diversity of CuI nanoclusters relate to the CuII source used in their synthesis?
questions.answer: The structural diversity of CuI nanoclusters is garnered by the CuII source, which furnishes a series of CuI nanoclusters containing increasing C2@ content, thus exhibiting higher cluster nuclearity and complexity.

questions.question: Why are compounds 1–4 considered potentially explosive under heating?
questions.answer: Compounds 1–4 are considered potentially explosive under heating due to the in situ generation of the reactive C2@ dianion, which can lead to uncontrollable reactions and the formation of highly explosive complexes.

questions.question: How does the synthesis of nanoclusters 1–4 expand the regime of CuI alkynide structural chemistry?
questions.answer: The synthesis of nanoclusters 1–4 expands the regime of CuI alkynide structural chemistry by demonstrating that nanocluster growth can be invoked by an increase in C2@ content, providing insight into Group 11 ethynediide chemistry.

questions.question: What is the significance of the Cu2C2 kernel in complex 4?
questions.answer: The Cu2C2 kernel in complex 4 represents a markedly more complex structure constructed from two kinds of units, C2@Cu6 (B) and C2@Cu7 (B), demonstrating an unprecedented highest-nuclearity Cu2C2 nanocluster.

questions.question: How does the synthesis approach of nanoclusters 1–4 differ from AgI and AuI chemistry?
questions.answer: The synthesis approach of nanoclusters 1–4 differs from AgI and AuI chemistry by capitalizing on the reactivity of CuI in alkyne reactions to generate the C2@ in situ, which has no precedence in AgI and AuI chemistry, thus providing a novel avenue for the development of coinage-metal-based carbon-rich clusters.

questions.question: Is the synthesis of nanoclusters 1–4 based on a temperature-mediated template release mechanism?
questions.answer: True

questions.question: Do nanoclusters 1–4 all contain the same C2@ content?
questions.answer: False

questions.question: Is the formation of highly explosive [CuI/C/C]1 complexes a desired outcome in the synthesis process?
questions.answer: False

questions.question: Does the synthesis of nanoclusters 1–4 involve the use of a single CuII source for all complexes?
questions.answer: False

questions.question: Are the photophysical properties of nanoclusters 1–3 identical?
questions.answer: False

questions.question: Is the Cu2C2 kernel in complex 4 unique to CuI alkynide chemistry?
questions.answer: True

questions.question: Does the synthesis of nanoclusters 1–4 provide insight into Group 11 ethynediide chemistry?
questions.answer: True

questions.question: Are nanoclusters 1–4 synthesized without considering the effect of co-existing anions?
questions.answer: False
